title: 111_hr5557
content: The Act is titled the "Back to School Act of 2010" and includes a provision for the "Back to School Credit." The "Back to School Act of 2010" includes a provision for the "Back to School Credit," allowing eligible individuals to claim a tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses paid during the taxable year. The credit is equal to the sum of expenses up to $2,000, plus 25% of expenses exceeding $2,000 but not exceeding $4,000. The tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses under the "Back to School Act of 2010" is equal to expenses up to $2,000, plus 25% of expenses exceeding $2,000 but not exceeding $4,000. The credit is subject to a reduction based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The applicable amount varies depending on filing status, with a higher limit for joint returns. The tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses has a limit of $60,000 for eligible individuals aged 55 or older who have not paid these expenses in the previous 5 years. The definition of 'tuition and related expense' includes expenses considered in determining a student's cost of attendance. The tax credit amounts for qualified tuition expenses are subject to inflation adjustments starting in 2011. The tax credit for qualified tuition expenses is adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, with rounding to the nearest multiple of $100. Income limits apply, with a threshold of $80,000 for taxable years starting after 2011. The tax credit for qualified tuition expenses is adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, with rounding to the nearest multiple of $1,000. The tax credit for qualified tuition expenses is adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, with rounding to the next lowest multiple of $1,000. Denial of credit applies if a student is convicted of a felony drug offense. Adjustments for certain scholarships and expenses paid by dependents are also addressed in the amendments, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010.
